content.question:
Calculate your expected fuel state at MALIV, after flying from NINTA to MALIV at FL60 with the following data given:
NINTA-MALIV: 189 NM
Usable fuel at NINTA: 560 kg
TAS at FL60: 155 kt
Wind component at FL60: -20 kt
Fuel flow: 195 kg/hr

key_points: The aircraft, flying at FL60 with TAS 155 kt experiencing a wind compnent of -20 kt (headwind), is actually flying with Groundspeed: 155 kt - 20 kt = 135 kt
The flight time from NINTA to MALIV is: Distance / GS = 189 NM /135 kt = 1
learning.explanation: The aircraft, flying at FL60 with TAS 155 kt experiencing a wind compnent of -20 kt (headwind), is actually flying with Groundspeed: 155 kt - 20 kt = 135 kt. The flight time from NINTA to MALIV is: Distance / GS = 189 NM /135 kt = 1.4 hr. With a fuel flow of 195 kg/hr, the fuel used for this distance under this condition is: 1.4 hr x 195 kg/hr = 273 kg. Thus, with usable fuel at NINTA 560 kg, the remaining fuel at MALIV will be: Usable fuel at NINTA - Fuel used from NINTA to MALIV = 560 kg - 273 kg = 287 kg.

content.question: What are the responsibilities of the commander of a Commercial Air Transport flight with regard to fuel in case of a diversion?

options.A: Remaining fuel should be at least the same as that required to reach an aerodrome or operating site where a safe landing can be made, with final reserve fuel remaining.
options.B: As a diversion is a spontaneous event, it is a criterion that lies outside of the commander’s responsibilities with regard to fuel to be on board.
options.C: Remaining fuel should be at least the same as that required to return to the aerodrome or operating site of departure.
options.D: Remaining fuel should be at least the same as that required to reach at least two different aerodromes or operating sites where a safe landing can be made, one of which can be the aerodrome or operating site of departure.

learning.explanation: Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 CAT. OP. MPA.280 In-flight fuel management – aeroplanes (b) In-flight fuel management (2) If an in-flight fuel check shows that the expected usable fuel remaining on arrival at the destination aerodrome is less than: (i) the required alternate fuel plus final reserve fuel, the commander shall take into account the traffic and the operational conditions prevailing at the destination aerodrome, at the destination alternate aerodrome and at any other adequate aerodrome in deciding whether to proceed to the destination aerodrome or to divert so as to perform a safe landing with not less than final reserve fuel; or (ii) the final reserve fuel if no alternate aerodrome is required, the commander shall take appropriate action and proceed to an adequate aerodrome so as to perform a safe landing with not less than final reserve fuel. (3) The commander shall declare an emergency when the calculated usable fuel on landing, at the nearest adequate aerodrome where a safe landing can be performed, is less than final reserve fuel.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Planning data as shown in the Flight Log excerpt (Fuel Planning Section). After a balked landing at the destination airport, you have to divert to the alternate airport with the gear extended. The re-calculated flight time to the alternate due to the reduced speed is 2 hrs 20 min and the fuel flow will be 780 kg/h. Final Reserve Fuel remains unchanged. What will be the estimated landing mass at the alternate airport?

key_points: We are given quite a lot of information, however, this question is quite simple and solved in 2 easy steps: (1) Calculate the Fuel Consumed to reach the alternate, when: Fuel Flow = 780 kg/h and flight time = 2 h 20 780 kg/h x 2 h 20 = 1820 kg (2) The estimated landing mass at the alternate airport will be equal to the Landing Mass at Destination (found in the attcahed Flight Log excerpt) minus the Fuel Consumed to reach the alternate: 7260 kg - 1820 kg = 5440 kg

content.question: What is the relationship between air distance and ground distance with a headwind?

options.A: Ground distance and air distance are independent of wind.
options.B: Air distance is greater than ground distance.
options.C: Ground distance is greater than air distance.
options.D: Air distance and ground distance are equal.

key_points: The air distance is the distance flown in a given time at a given TAS
TAS is the aircraft’s speed through the atmosphere
The ground distance is the distance covered over the Earth’s surface
learning.explanation: The air distance is the distance flown in a given time at a given TAS. TAS is the aircraft’s speed through the atmosphere. The ground distance is the distance covered over the Earth’s surface. Ground speed is the aircraft’s speed over the Earth’s surface, i.e. the resulting speed that the aircraft travels across the Earth’s surface when wind is applied to the TAS. The ground speed is calculated by subtracting a headwind component or adding a tailwind component from TAS: Ground speed = TAS + tailwind component or Ground speed = TAS - headwind component Therefore, with a headwind, air distance is greater than ground distance. Note: This particular question falls outside the scope of Flight Planning (033); however, it has been brought to our attention that a student encountered it in their exam.
